Triggering Event: She's been on her feet all day, the heat of the kitchen amplifying her anger. As she slices through vegetables with excessive force, a customer sends back their perfectly cooked steak, complaining it's underseasoned. She slams down the knife, storms out to the dining room, and screams at the diner, "You don't know what you're talking about!" before storming back to the kitchen, leaving her staff in stunned silence.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I can totally relate to this situation. When I was working at Starbucks, I had an incredibly tough time dealing with customers. One woman constantly sent her drinks back, saying they were too cold. I'd have to remake them multiple times, which made me really frustrated because I already worked so hard. Eventually, I started yelling at her, just like that other girl. I remember feeling so angry, but then my manager told me to calm down and apologize. It was such a relief when I did. Now I'm just glad I didn't get fired for losing control.

I wonder if he's just trying to make himself feel better." But when he saw how upset he got, he decided to confront him. "You know, I've been feeling pretty good lately. I even went on vacation recently," he said calmly, his voice firm but gentle. "So, why are you still looking for that kid?" His friend looked taken aback by the question, and for a moment, he seemed unsure of how to respond. "I...I don't know," he stuttered. "Maybe I just can't let go of my guilt." His friend sighed inwardly, processing the situation. He had known this guy since they were kids, and he knew how much this case meant to him. Yet, he couldn't shake off the feeling that there must be more to it than just guilt. "Look, I understand that this has been bothering you for a while, but I think it's time we moved on. There’s no new evidence—" But his friend cut him off, his voice rising. “No new evidence? How can you say that? We’ve talked to every single witness, every single family member, and yet...”

Triggering Event: Every evening, after grading papers and preparing lessons for the next day, he would sit alone in their old kitchen, staring at her empty chair by the window where sunlight used to dance on her face. Today, he noticed a withered plant she'd loved tending to, its leaves brown and brittle, like memories that refuse to fade. He reached out to touch it, but his hand paused mid-air, trembling slightly. A sob escaped him, raw and unexpected, echoing through the silent house.

It didn't make sense, and I felt frustrated that he couldn't just be calm like usual. But as we talked more, I realized he must have been thinking about something deeply personal, and I didn't want to intrude on his emotions. Yet, why did it always seem like he got so worked up over nothing? I know he's sensitive, but shouldn't he learn to handle stress better? When he told me about the withered plant, I felt annoyed that he was making such a big deal out of it. It wasn’t even that special, just another plant he’d forgotten to water. Still, he kept talking about how much she liked it and how sad it made him feel. I tried to reassure him that it’s okay to remember happy times, but he insisted that it was more than that—it was an actual memory he cherished. Now, whenever I see plants, I think about how easily they can die, and it makes me uncomfortable because it reminds me of all the things that could go wrong in life. Sometimes, I wonder if his emotional outbursts are actually connected to something deeper. Maybe he’s struggling with feelings he doesn’t know how to process, and it’s hard for him to open up about them. Triggering Event: He stood at the counter, ringing up Mrs. Thompson's groceries, his hands trembling slightly from the cold. He watched her pull out a crisp fifty-dollar bill to pay for her items, her eyes twinkling as she mentioned her grandson's recent promotion. He felt a pang in his chest, envying not just her wealth, but also her joy and family warmth, things he hadn't known since his wife passed.

She had a lot of money, and it wasn’t fair that she got all the good stuff while he struggled to make ends meet. It seemed like she was rubbing it in his face, flaunting her prosperity right under his nose. I wish there was something I could do about it, but what’s the point? Life isn’t fair anyway, so why bother trying? It’s ridiculous how much she has, especially after seeing her son’s success. The world is full of people who don’t deserve as much as they get. If only I had some of her luck, maybe I wouldn’t be so stressed. But no, life just isn’t fair—so what’s the use? Maybe I’ll just focus on myself and forget about everyone else’s problems. At least then I won’t feel so guilty about being miserable. There must be more to this story. He didn’t seem happy paying that big bill. I wonder if he has some secret resentment toward her.
